key: _claude-sonnet-4__How does the evidence for using acoustic devices to reduce human-wildlife conflict at aquaculture systems compare to their use on fishing gear?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The evidence for acoustic devices to reduce human-wildlife conflict differs substantially between aquaculture systems and fishing gear contexts.
[Statement 2]: At aquaculture systems, four of six evaluated studies found that acoustic devices reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals and South American sea lions.
[Statement 3]: At aquaculture systems, four of six evaluated studies found that acoustic devices reduced the number of harbour seals approaching fish cages.
[Statement 4]: Two studies found that acoustic devices did not reduce harbour seal predation at salmon farms.
[Statement 5]: Two studies found that acoustic devices did not reduce the presence, approach distances, group sizes or time spent around fin-fish farms by common bottlenose dolphins.
[Statement 6]: For fishing gear, thirty-three studies were evaluated, showing much more extensive evidence for the effectiveness of acoustic devices.
[Statement 7]: Five of six controlled studies on fishing gear found that acoustic devices reduced damage to fish catches and/or fishing nets caused by common bottlenose dolphins and seals.
[Statement 8]: One study found acoustic devices did not reduce damage to swordfish catches by California sea lions.
[Statement 9]: Studies on fishing gear demonstrated significant evidence for reducing entanglements.
[Statement 10]: Nine studies found that acoustic devices on fishing gear resulted in fewer collisions of humpback whales.
[Statement 11]: Nine studies found that acoustic devices on fishing gear resulted in fewer entanglements of harbour porpoises, Franciscana dolphins, beaked whales and small cetaceans.
[Statement 12]: The fishing gear evidence base is substantially larger than the aquaculture evidence base.
[Statement 13]: The evidence for acoustic devices on fishing gear shows broader applications across more marine mammal species and geographical locations.
[Statement 14]: Acoustic devices on fishing gear demonstrated effectiveness for both reducing unwanted catch/entanglements and human-wildlife conflict.
[Statement 15]: Aquaculture studies on acoustic devices focused primarily on predation reduction at fish farms.

[Statement 1]: The evidence shows different levels of effectiveness between attaching acoustically reflective objects to fishing gear and using acoustically reflective fishing gear materials for reducing marine mammal entanglement.
[Statement 2]: Two studies conducted on attaching acoustically reflective objects to fishing gear both showed no effectiveness.
[Statement 3]: One controlled study in the Timor Sea and Arafura Sea found that attaching metallic bead chains to fishing nets did not reduce dolphin entanglements.
[Statement 4]: One controlled study in the Gulf of Alaska found that attaching acrylic beads next to fishing hooks did not reduce predation on fish catches by sperm whales.
[Statement 5]: Using acoustically reflective fishing gear materials showed more promising results based on five studies conducted across multiple locations.
[Statement 6]: Two of three controlled studies in the North Sea, Bay of Fundy, and South Atlantic Ocean found that fishing nets made from acoustically reflective materials (iron-oxide or barium sulfate) had fewer entanglements of harbour porpoises than conventional fishing nets.
[Statement 7]: One study found that nets made from barium sulfate did not reduce dolphin entanglements.
[Statement 8]: Two behavioural studies examined how harbour porpoises responded to acoustically reflective materials.
[Statement 9]: One study found that porpoises approached both barium sulfate and conventional nets similarly.
[Statement 10]: One study found that porpoises used fewer echolocation clicks at barium sulfate nets.
[Statement 11]: Another study found that harbour porpoise echolocation activity was similar at both acoustically reflective and conventional net types.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__How does the evidence for using acoustically reflective materials on fishing gear compare to attaching acoustically reflective objects for reducing marine mammal entanglement?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Evidence shows multiple direct management interventions for boosting threatened mammal populations exist.
[Statement 2]: Direct management interventions for boosting threatened mammal populations have varying success rates.
[Statement 3]: Captive breeding and release programs demonstrate mixed results.
[Statement 4]: Studies from 31 locations found that captive-bred mammals had lower post-release survival rates than wild-born translocated animals.
[Statement 5]: Populations of mountain gazelles, Corsican red deer, PÃ¨re David's deer, Eurasian otters and swift foxes increased following releases.
[Statement 6]: Review evidence indicates over half of mammal release programmes were considered successful.
[Statement 7]: Release programmes for macropods resulted in successful establishment in 61% of cases.
[Statement 8]: 40% of released macropods survived for over five years.
[Statement 9]: Translocation shows promise as a management intervention for marine mammals.
[Statement 10]: Between 50% and 83% of translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups survived for at least one year.
[Statement 11]: The survival rates for translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups were similar to non-translocated pups born at release sites.
[Statement 12]: More than a quarter of translocated Hawaiian monk seals reproduced when translocation was combined with other interventions.
[Statement 13]: For captive-bred marine mammals, two of three Antillean manatees born in captivity and released survived for at least one year.
[Statement 14]: Two of 14 Florida manatees born in captivity and released survived for at least one year.
[Statement 15]: Holding translocated mammals in captivity before release increased survival rates.
[Statement 16]: Longer pre-release captivity periods improved the survival of European hedgehogs and Canada lynx.
[Statement 17]: Translocated animals held in captivity prior to release had higher post-release survival rates than captive-bred animals released directly.
[Statement 18]: Providing artificial refuges and breeding sites enhances the success of mammal release programs.
[Statement 19]: Release sites with artificial burrows had higher abundances of European rabbits and California ground squirrels compared to sites without artificial burrows.
[Statement 20]: Translocated European ground squirrels released into plugged artificial burrows had higher recapture rates than those in unplugged burrows.
[Statement 21]: Supplementary feeding provides population support for threatened mammals.
[Statement 22]: Studies found supplementary feeding increased the abundance of bank voles, red squirrels, striped mice, brown hyena and black-backed jackals.
[Statement 23]: Supplementary feeding increased reproductive rates in ungulates in five of eight studies.
[Statement 24]: Supplementary feeding increased survival in ungulates in four out of seven studies.
[Statement 25]: Supplementary feeding increased the proportion of striped mice that were breeding.
[Statement 26]: Supplementary feeding increased the number of arctic fox litters.
[Statement 27]: Supplementary feeding increased the litter sizes of prairie voles.
[Statement 28]: Genetic management techniques show limited evidence of success.
[Statement 29]: Artificial insemination resulted in fewer than half of female black-footed ferrets giving birth.
[Statement 30]: Artificial insemination resulted in lower pregnancy rates in giant pandas compared to natural mating.
[Statement 31]: Artificial insemination using preserved genetic material increased genetic diversity in captive black-footed ferret populations.
[Statement 32]: Artificial insemination using preserved genetic material lowered inbreeding in captive black-footed ferret populations.
[Statement 33]: The success of primate reintroduction varies by the rearing method used.
[Statement 34]: Most reintroduced golden lion tamarins born and reared in cages had higher mortality than wild-born tamarins.
[Statement 35]: Most reintroduced golden lion tamarins born and reared in cages did not survive over seven years.
[Statement 36]: Only two out of three black lion tamarins raised in free-ranging environments survived over four months.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the evidence for interventions that directly manage individual mammals to boost threatened populations?
_claude-sonnet-4__What are the potential negative impacts associated with using acoustic deterrent devices for marine mammal conservation?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several potential negative impacts and limitations of acoustic deterrent devices for marine mammal conservation can be identified.
[Statement 2]: Killer whale distances from fishing vessels decreased after the first exposure to acoustic devices, suggesting habituation may occur.
[Statement 3]: The probability of harbour porpoises approaching within 125 meters of acoustic devices increased over 10-11 days, indicating habituation effects.
[Statement 4]: Acoustic deterrent devices have shown inconsistent effectiveness.
[Statement 5]: Acoustic devices did not reduce harbour seal predation at some salmon farms.
[Statement 6]: Acoustic devices did not reduce the presence of common bottlenose dolphins around fin-fish farms.
[Statement 7]: Acoustic devices on fishing vessels can reduce surfacing and echolocation rates of Indo-Pacific humpback dolphins and Australian snubfin dolphins.
[Statement 8]: A reduction in surfacing and echolocation rates in dolphins could potentially interfere with the dolphins' natural behaviors.
[Statement 9]: Acoustic devices on fishing gear were effective for some species but not others, indicating variable effectiveness.
[Statement 10]: Acoustic devices on fishing gear were effective in some fishing areas but not others.
[Statement 11]: Harmful deterrents exist at aquaculture systems and require regulation.

[Statement 1]: Based on evidence from the Atlantic and North Sea regions, several interventions have demonstrated effectiveness for reducing cetacean bycatch in fishing nets.
[Statement 2]: Acoustic devices on fishing gear showed the strongest evidence for reducing cetacean bycatch.
[Statement 3]: Twelve of 16 controlled studies found that acoustic devices on fishing nets resulted in harbour porpoises, common bottlenose dolphins and other cetaceans approaching nets less closely.
[Statement 4]: The same twelve studies also found that these cetaceans had fewer encounters with nets equipped with acoustic devices.
[Statement 5]: Nine studies in the North Atlantic Ocean and North Sea found that acoustic devices on fishing nets resulted in fewer entanglements of harbour porpoises, Franciscana dolphins, beaked whales and small cetaceans.
[Statement 6]: The effectiveness of acoustic devices on fishing nets varied by fishing area in some cases.
[Statement 7]: Acoustically reflective fishing gear materials showed promise for reducing cetacean bycatch.
[Statement 8]: Two of three controlled studies in the North Sea and Bay of Fundy found that nets made from acoustically reflective materials, such as iron-oxide or barium sulfate, had fewer entanglements of harbour porpoises than conventional fishing nets.
[Statement 9]: One study found that barium sulfate nets did not reduce dolphin entanglements.
[Statement 10]: Acoustic devices on fishing vessels showed limited evidence for reducing cetacean bycatch in Atlantic regions.
[Statement 11]: One controlled study in the North Atlantic Ocean found that acoustic devices on fishing vessels did not reduce predation of squid catches by Risso's dolphins.
[Statement 12]: Attaching acoustically reflective objects to fishing gear showed no effectiveness in reducing cetacean bycatch.
[Statement 13]: One controlled study found that attaching metallic bead chains to fishing nets did not reduce dolphin entanglements.
[Statement 14]: Escape devices fitted to encircling nets showed some promise for reducing unwanted catch.
[Statement 15]: There is limited specific evidence for cetacean bycatch reduction using escape devices in the Atlantic and North Sea regions.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the most effective interventions for reducing cetacean bycatch in fishing nets, based on evidence from the Atlantic and North Sea?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Evidence for the success of releasing hand-reared or captive-bred manatees back into the wild in the Americas shows mixed but generally positive outcomes.
[Statement 2]: Approximately three-quarters of Antillean manatees that were captive-reared and released in the South Atlantic Ocean in Brazil were known to survive for at least one year.
[Statement 3]: Some captive-reared Antillean manatees that were released in the South Atlantic Ocean survived for more than seven years.
[Statement 4]: Two-thirds of Florida manatees that were captive-reared and released in water bodies in Florida survived for at least one year.
[Statement 5]: Most captive-reared Antillean manatees released back into the wild in the South Atlantic Ocean reproduced.
[Statement 6]: The reproduction of captive-reared Antillean manatees released into the wild indicates successful integration.
[Statement 7]: Three captive-reared West Indian manatee calves either died before or after release, had to be returned to captivity after release, or survived in the wild only with supplemental feeding.
[Statement 8]: Evidence shows lower success rates for releasing manatees that were specifically captive-bred.
[Statement 9]: Two of three Antillean manatees born in captivity and released in the Porto de Pedras estuary in Brazil survived for at least one year without further intervention.
[Statement 10]: Two of fourteen Florida manatees born in captivity and released in water bodies in Florida survived for at least one year without further intervention.
[Statement 11]: General rehabilitation data shows that 10-100% of manatees released after rehabilitation in captivity survived during post-release monitoring periods.
[Statement 12]: Post-release monitoring periods for rehabilitated manatees ranged from three days to five years.
[Statement 13]: Rehabilitated manatees were monitored in various locations including the Gulf of Mexico, the Indian River Lagoon, and water bodies in Florida.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the evidence for the success of releasing hand-reared or captive-bred manatees back into the wild in the Americas?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Catch protection devices on longlines showed mixed effectiveness in reducing human-wildlife conflict.
[Statement 2]: Two of four studies found that net sleeves or cage and chain devices on fishing hooks reduced damage to fish catches by sperm whales, killer whales and toothed whales.
[Statement 3]: Two other studies found that attaching 'umbrella' or 'spider' devices on fishing hooks did not reduce predation and/or damage to fish catches by sperm whales or toothed whales.
[Statement 4]: One study found that catch protection devices made from streamers reduced dolphin predation on fish bait, but only during the first two trials.
[Statement 5]: Modifying fishing pots and traps showed more consistent positive outcomes for reducing human-wildlife conflict.
[Statement 6]: Two controlled studies found that installing wire grids or steel bars on fishing trap-nets or bag-nets, along with strengthened netting or other modifications to prevent seal access, reduced damage to salmon catches by seals.
[Statement 7]: One study found that one of two methods of securing crab pot doors with a bungee cord reduced common bottlenose dolphin interactions.
[Statement 8]: One study found that installing wire grids on trap-nets, along with strengthened netting, resulted in higher catches of undamaged salmon but not whitefish.
[Statement 9]: The higher catches of undamaged salmon were likely due to reduced seal predation.
[Statement 10]: Both catch protection devices and modified fishing pots showed effectiveness in reducing entanglements and unwanted catch.
[Statement 11]: Catch protection devices resulted in fewer unwanted catches of toothed whales.
[Statement 12]: Modified fishing pots reduced the number of Australian sea lion pups or grey seals and harbour seals that entered or became trapped in pots.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__How do the outcomes of using catch protection devices on longlines compare to modifying fishing pots for reducing human-wildlife conflict?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several interventions are available to mitigate underwater noise impacts from construction activities like pile driving.
[Statement 2]: Bubble curtains or screens can be used to dampen underwater noise emissions during pile driving.
[Statement 3]: One study in the North Sea found that using bubble curtains or screens resulted in a smaller decrease in harbour porpoise detections within 15 km compared to sites without these measures.
[Statement 4]: Reducing hammer energy during pile driving is a potential intervention for mitigating underwater noise.
[Statement 5]: No studies have yet evaluated the effectiveness of reducing hammer energy on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
[Statement 6]: 'Soft start' procedures can be used to deter marine and freshwater mammals to reduce the animals' noise exposure.
[Statement 7]: Studies have shown that a greater proportion of cetaceans avoided or moved away from vessels during 'soft start' procedures.
[Statement 8]: The effects of 'soft start' procedures on cetaceans varied by species and situation.
[Statement 9]: Acoustic devices can be deployed to deter marine and freshwater mammals from construction areas.
[Statement 10]: Studies at wind farm construction sites have shown reduced activity and sightings of harbour porpoises at distances of 1-18 km from acoustic devices.
[Statement 11]: An additional intervention is to delay or cease operations if marine mammals are detected within specified zones.
[Statement 12]: No studies have evaluated the effectiveness of delaying or ceasing operations when marine mammals are detected within specified zones.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What interventions are available to mitigate the impacts of underwater noise from construction activities like pile driving?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Education and community engagement programs have shown several documented effects on human behavior towards marine mammals.
[Statement 2]: After educational whale-watching tours or educational exhibitions, participants were more willing to change their behavior to support marine conservation.
[Statement 3]: After educational whale-watching tours or educational exhibitions, participants were more willing to donate money to marine conservation.
[Statement 4]: After educational whale-watching tours or educational exhibitions, participants were more willing to cut their fishing nets to save entangled dolphins.
[Statement 5]: A study in the Kenai Fjords, Alaska demonstrated that training tourist guides resulted in fewer harbor seals being disturbed during kayak excursions.
[Statement 6]: Not all educational interventions have shown positive effects.
[Statement 7]: A controlled study in New Zealand found that tourist groups that observed information signs approached and disturbed New Zealand fur seals in similar numbers to tourist groups that did not observe signs.
[Statement 8]: Education programs for ranchers in South Africa, combined with stricter hunting policies, increased leopard density.
[Statement 9]: Education programs for ranchers in South Africa, combined with stricter hunting policies, reduced leopard mortalities.
[Statement 10]: Household education about garbage dangers to black bears in the USA did not increase the use of wildlife-resistant dumpsters.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the documented effects of education and community engagement programs on human behaviour towards marine mammals?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The benefits of using acoustic devices on fishing gear include reduced entanglements and collisions for marine mammals, including harbour porpoises.
[Statement 2]: Acoustic devices on fishing nets and cod traps resulted in fewer entanglements of harbour porpoises, Franciscana dolphins, beaked whales and small cetaceans.
[Statement 3]: One study found that fishing nets with a 'complete' set of acoustic devices had fewer entanglements of harbour porpoises.
[Statement 4]: Controlled studies found that acoustic devices resulted in harbour porpoises, common bottlenose dolphins, and other species approaching nets less closely.
[Statement 5]: Controlled studies found that acoustic devices resulted in some species having fewer encounters with nets.
[Statement 6]: Controlled studies found that acoustic devices resulted in reduced activity for some species in surrounding areas.
[Statement 7]: The effectiveness of acoustic devices varies by location.
[Statement 8]: The effectiveness of acoustic devices varies by the completeness of implementation.
[Statement 9]: One study found that fishing nets with an 'incomplete' set of acoustic devices did not reduce harbour porpoise entanglements.
[Statement 10]: Another study found that acoustic devices reduced harbour porpoise entanglements in one fishing area but not in another.
[Statement 11]: Four studies found that acoustic devices did not have significant effects on the behaviour of common bottlenose dolphins, harbour porpoises, Indo-Pacific humpback dolphins or dugongs.
[Statement 12]: Evidence suggests displacement effects where porpoises and other marine mammals avoid areas with acoustic devices.
[Statement 13]: Studies found that acoustic devices caused porpoises to approach nets less closely and reduced activity in surrounding areas, which represents a form of habitat displacement.
[Statement 14]: Studies on acoustic devices used for noise exposure reduction showed the devices could reduce harbour porpoise activity and sightings at distances of 1-18 km from the devices.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the benefits and harms of using acoustic devices on fishing gear in coastal waters to protect porpoises?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The evidence base for actions designed to mitigate the risks of renewable energy infrastructure to marine and freshwater mammals is extremely limited.
[Statement 2]: For the vast majority of mitigation actions, no studies were found that evaluated their effects.
[Statement 3]: No studies have evaluated the effects on marine and freshwater mammal populations of using real-time automated tools to detect the mammals and allow operations to be stopped or modified.
[Statement 4]: No studies have evaluated the effects on marine and freshwater mammals of using acoustic devices at renewable energy sites.
[Statement 5]: No studies have evaluated the effects on marine and freshwater mammals of modifying the design of underwater turbines.
[Statement 6]: No studies have evaluated the effects on marine and freshwater mammals of translocating the mammal species before the onset of impactful activities.
[Statement 7]: No studies have evaluated the effects on marine and freshwater mammal populations of reducing hammer energy during pile driving.
[Statement 8]: No studies have evaluated the effects on marine and freshwater mammals of modifying vessels to reduce noise disturbance.
[Statement 9]: No studies have evaluated the effects on marine and freshwater mammal populations of limiting, ceasing or prohibiting the discharge of cooling effluents from power stations.
[Statement 10]: The only mitigation action with any evidence is using methods to dampen underwater noise emissions such as bubble curtains or screens.
[Statement 11]: A study in the North Sea found that using bubble curtains or screens during pile driving resulted in harbour porpoise detections within 15 km decreasing less compared to before pile driving than at sites without bubble curtains or screens.
[Statement 12]: Rehabilitating and releasing injured, sick or weak marine and freshwater mammals has been evaluated by 27 studies, though this is not specifically a renewable energy mitigation action.
[Statement 13]: Studies found that 10-100% of various marine mammals released after rehabilitation survived during post-release monitoring periods ranging from three days to five years.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the state of the evidence for actions designed to mitigate the risks of renewable energy infrastructure to marine and freshwater mammals?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The evidence for modifying fishing pots and traps to exclude mammals comes from six studies conducted in various locations including the North Sea, Indian River Lagoon, Gulf of Finland, Bothnian Sea, Indian Ocean, and Baltic Sea.
[Statement 2]: Installing steel rods on lobster pots or metal frames on fishing pots reduced the number of Australian sea lion pups or grey seals and harbour seals that entered or became trapped in pots.
[Statement 3]: Installing wire grids or steel bars on fishing trap-nets or bag-nets, along with strengthened netting, reduced damage to salmon catches by seals.
[Statement 4]: The use of modified fishing trap-nets or bag-nets resulted in higher catches of undamaged salmon due to reduced seal predation.
[Statement 5]: The evidence for installing exclusion and/or escape devices on fishing nets for mammals comes from seven studies in the Indian Ocean, the Tasman Sea, and the South Atlantic Ocean.
[Statement 6]: Installing exclusion and/or escape devices on trawl nets reduced the number of trapped or entangled Antarctic fur seals and common bottlenose dolphins.
[Statement 7]: Evidence revealed that less than one third of common bottlenose dolphins exited escape hatches on trawl nets alive.
[Statement 8]: Fewer fur seals died in exclusion devices with large escape openings than in those with small openings.
[Statement 9]: Both modifying fishing pots and installing net exclusion devices showed evidence of reducing unwanted catch.
[Statement 10]: Pot and trap modifications appear to have more studies demonstrating reduced damage to target catches.
[Statement 11]: Net exclusion devices showed mixed results regarding the survival rates of mammals that encountered the devices.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__How does the evidence for modifying fishing pots and traps to exclude mammals compare with installing exclusion or escape devices on fishing nets?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Using baited lines instead of nets for shark control is the best available method to minimize harm to non-target marine mammals in the South Pacific and Indian Oceans.
[Statement 2]: Studies in the Indian Ocean and South Pacific Ocean found that baited lines used for shark control had fewer entanglements of dolphins, whales and dugongs than nets.
[Statement 3]: One study in the South Pacific Ocean found that using baited lines instead of nets increased the survival of entangled common and bottlenose dolphins.
[Statement 4]: As a complementary approach, acoustic devices on fishing gear have been shown to be effective in the South Pacific and Indian Oceans.
[Statement 5]: Studies found that acoustic devices resulted in fewer entanglements of small cetaceans and beaked whales.
[Statement 6]: Acoustic devices caused marine mammals to approach nets less closely.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__In the South Pacific and Indian Oceans, what is the best available method for shark control programs to minimize harm to non-target marine mammals?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Acoustic devices used for marine mammal conservation present several trade-offs between effectiveness and behavioral impacts.
[Statement 2]: While acoustic devices can be effective for reducing unwanted interactions, the devices also cause significant behavioral changes in marine mammals.
[Statement 3]: Acoustic devices successfully deter mammals from areas to reduce noise exposure.
[Statement 4]: Studies found reduced activity and sightings of harbour porpoises at distances of 1-18 km from acoustic devices.
[Statement 5]: Minke whales increased swimming speed and swam more directly when acoustic devices were deployed.
[Statement 6]: Acoustic devices on moorings reduced the numbers of grey and harbour seals.
[Statement 7]: Acoustic devices on moorings reduced the activity of harbour porpoises, short-beaked common dolphins and common bottlenose dolphins.
[Statement 8]: The effectiveness of acoustic devices varied by species, as the devices had no significant effect on humpback whale behavior.
[Statement 9]: Acoustic devices on fishing vessels caused common bottlenose dolphins to avoid boats more frequently.
[Statement 10]: Acoustic devices on fishing vessels reduced surfacing, echolocation rates, and time spent foraging or socializing in Indo-Pacific humpback dolphins and Australian snubfin dolphins.
[Statement 11]: Acoustic devices on fishing gear successfully reduced entanglements of various species including harbour porpoises, Franciscana dolphins, and beaked whales.
[Statement 12]: Acoustic devices on fishing gear also caused behavioral changes including reduced approaches to nets and decreased activity in surrounding areas.
[Statement 13]: Acoustic devices at aquaculture systems reduced predation by seals and sea lions.
[Statement 14]: Acoustic devices at aquaculture systems had inconsistent effects across species and locations.
[Statement 15]: While acoustic devices can reduce immediate mammal presence, the probability of porpoises approaching within 125 m increased over 10-11 days.
[Statement 16]: The increase in porpoise approaches suggests potential habituation effects that could reduce the long-term effectiveness of acoustic devices.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the potential trade-offs associated with using acoustic devices for marine mammal conservation?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The evidence for actions aimed at mitigating pollution threats to marine mammals from agricultural and sewage sources shows a complete absence of studies that directly evaluate these interventions.
[Statement 2]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects on marine and freshwater mammal populations of setting or improving minimum sewage treatment standards.
[Statement 3]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects on marine and freshwater mammal populations of treating wastewater from intensive livestock holdings.
[Statement 4]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects on marine and freshwater mammal populations of limiting, ceasing or prohibiting the dumping of untreated sewage.
[Statement 5]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects on marine and freshwater mammal populations of limiting, ceasing or prohibiting the dumping of sewage sludge.
[Statement 6]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects on marine and freshwater mammal populations of establishing riparian buffers to reduce pollutants reaching rivers and the sea.
[Statement 7]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects on marine and freshwater mammal populations of reducing pesticide, herbicide or fertilizer use.
[Statement 8]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects on marine and freshwater mammal populations of creating artificial wetlands to reduce pollutants reaching rivers and the sea.
[Statement 9]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects on marine and freshwater mammal populations of establishing aquaculture to extract nutrients from run-offs.
[Statement 10]: No evidence was found for the effects on amphibian populations of preventing pollution from agricultural lands or sewage treatment facilities from entering watercourses.
[Statement 11]: No studies were found evaluating the effects on bat populations of preventing pollution from agricultural land or forestry from entering watercourses.
[Statement 12]: A consistent lack of evidence across all actions indicates that the effectiveness of interventions for protecting marine mammals from agricultural and sewage pollution threats has not been scientifically documented.
[Statement 13]: While interventions to mitigate pollution exist as potential strategies, their effectiveness has not been scientifically documented.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the evidence for actions aimed at mitigating pollution threats to marine mammals from agricultural and sewage sources?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several strategies are identified for reducing negative impacts of aquaculture systems on marine mammals.
[Statement 2]: Evidence for the effectiveness of strategies to reduce the negative impacts of aquaculture systems on marine mammals is limited.
[Statement 3]: Translocating marine and freshwater mammal species before the onset of impactful activities is a translocation strategy.
[Statement 4]: No studies have evaluated the effects of the strategy to translocate marine and freshwater mammal species.
[Statement 5]: Locating aquaculture systems in vegetated areas is a site selection strategy.
[Statement 6]: Locating aquaculture systems in already impacted areas is a site selection strategy.
[Statement 7]: Locating aquaculture systems in areas with fast currents is a site selection strategy.
[Statement 8]: No studies have evaluated the approaches of locating aquaculture systems in vegetated areas, in already impacted areas, or in areas with fast currents.
[Statement 9]: Reducing the amount of antibiotics used in aquaculture systems is a chemical management strategy.
[Statement 10]: Using non-toxic antifouling coatings on surfaces in aquaculture is a chemical management strategy.
[Statement 11]: No studies have evaluated the effects of reducing antibiotics or using non-toxic antifouling coatings on marine mammals.
[Statement 12]: Modifying anti-predator nets around aquaculture systems is a management strategy.
[Statement 13]: Installing and maintaining anti-predator systems that prevent entanglement is a management strategy.
[Statement 14]: Replacing or repairing damaged anti-predator nets around aquaculture systems is a management strategy.
[Statement 15]: One study found that replacing anti-predator nets more frequently at salmon farms resulted in fewer salmon losses to harbour seal predation.
[Statement 16]: Using sterile individuals in aquaculture systems that use non-native species is a containment and species management strategy.
[Statement 17]: Using bioremediation methods in aquaculture is a containment and species management strategy.
[Statement 18]: Reducing and/or eradicating aquaculture escapees in the wild is a containment and species management strategy.
[Statement 19]: No studies have evaluated the approaches of using sterile individuals, using bioremediation, or reducing aquaculture escapees.
[Statement 20]: The evidence base for most strategies to reduce the negative impacts of aquaculture on marine mammals is very limited.
[Statement 21]: Only one study was identified that evaluated the effectiveness of replacing anti-predator nets.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the available strategies to reduce the negative impacts of aquaculture systems on marine mammals?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: No comparative evidence exists for the effectiveness of legislation preventing the intentional killing of mammals at aquaculture systems versus at wild fisheries.
[Statement 2]: No studies have evaluated the effects of introducing and enforcing legislation to prevent intentional killing of mammals at aquaculture systems.
[Statement 3]: No studies have evaluated the effects of introducing and enforcing legislation to prevent intentional killing of mammals at wild fisheries.
[Statement 4]: No studies have directly evaluated legislative approaches to prevent the intentional killing of mammals during systematic journal and report searches.
[Statement 5]: There is currently no evidence base to assess whether legislation to prevent the intentional killing of mammals is effective in either aquaculture or wild fishery contexts.
[Statement 6]: There is currently no evidence base to assess whether legislation to prevent the intentional killing of mammals has any harmful impacts in either aquaculture or wild fishery contexts.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the comparative evidence for the effectiveness of legislation preventing the intentional killing of mammals at aquaculture systems versus at wild fisheries?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Four studies have evaluated the behavioral effects of implementing regulations for marine and freshwater mammal watching tours.
[Statement 2]: Studies evaluating the effects of implementing regulations for mammal watching tours were conducted in the North Atlantic Ocean, the CananÃ©ia estuary in Brazil, the South Pacific Ocean in Australia, and the Bass Strait in Australia.
[Statement 3]: Two controlled studies found that when whale-watching vessels followed approach regulations, fewer sperm whales and humpback whale pods changed their behaviours or avoided the vessels compared to when regulations were not followed.
[Statement 4]: When whale-watching vessels followed approach regulations, the direction of movement and diving patterns of sperm whales and humpback whales did not differ from when regulations were not followed.
[Statement 5]: A study in the CananÃ©ia estuary found that when tour boats followed approach regulations, fewer Guiana dolphins displayed negative behaviours such as moving away, diving, or groups separating.
[Statement 6]: A study in the Bass Strait found that when boats approached a seal colony to 75 meters, more seals remained on shore than when boats approached to 25 meters.
[Statement 7]: A study in the Kenai Fjords, Alaska, found that fewer harbour seals were disturbed during kayak excursions after training was provided to kayak guides.
[Statement 8]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of developing and implementing regulations for operating vessels around mammals generally.
[Statement 9]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of introducing permits or licences for marine and freshwater mammal watching tours.
[Statement 10]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of providing training to vessel operators on mammal behaviour and appropriate avoidance techniques.
[Statement 11]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of setting minimum distances for approaching mammals.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the documented behavioral effects on marine mammals of implementing regulations for vessel operations during tourism activities?
_claude-sonnet-4__What are the demonstrated benefits of prohibiting the hunting of marine mammals?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The documented benefits of prohibiting marine mammal hunting include significant population increases across multiple species.
[Statement 2]: Four of five studies found that after hunting was prohibited, the abundance of harbour seals and humpback whales increased over 7-30 years in the Kattegat and Skagerrak Seas, the South Pacific Ocean, the North Atlantic Ocean and the Southern Ocean.
[Statement 3]: A review covering the North Atlantic Ocean, North Pacific Ocean and the Southern Hemisphere found significant increase rates for 10 of 12 baleen whale populations during 7-21 years after legislation to prohibit hunting was introduced.
[Statement 4]: One study found that numbers of mature male sperm whales did not differ significantly before or 31 years after hunting was prohibited.
[Statement 5]: The evidence demonstrates that hunting prohibitions generally lead to population recovery in marine mammal species over periods ranging from 7 to 30 years.
[Statement 6]: The evidence demonstrates that hunting prohibitions generally lead to abundance increases in marine mammal species over periods ranging from 7 to 30 years.

[Statement 1]: The evidence for alternative methods to nets in shark control programs comes primarily from studies evaluating baited lines as an alternative to nets.
[Statement 2]: Two studies from the Indian Ocean and South Pacific Ocean found that using baited lines instead of nets for shark control had fewer entanglements of dolphins, whales and dugongs.
[Statement 3]: A site comparison study in the South Pacific Ocean found that using baited lines instead of nets increased the survival of entangled common and bottlenose dolphins.
[Statement 4]: For reducing harm from fishing nets more generally, several methods show promise.
[Statement 5]: Installing exclusion and/or escape devices on fishing nets reduced the number of trapped or entangled Antarctic fur seals and common bottlenose dolphins in studies from the South Atlantic Ocean and Indian Ocean.
[Statement 6]: Less than one third of common bottlenose dolphins exited escape hatches on trawl nets alive in one Indian Ocean study.
[Statement 7]: Acoustic devices on fishing gear showed mixed results across multiple locations including Australia.
[Statement 8]: Nine studies found that using acoustic devices on cod traps or fishing nets resulted in fewer collisions of humpback whales.
[Statement 9]: Nine studies found that using acoustic devices on cod traps or fishing nets resulted in fewer entanglements of harbour porpoises, Franciscana dolphins, beaked whales and small cetaceans.
[Statement 10]: Three studies found that acoustic devices resulted in fewer entanglements of some species but not others.
[Statement 11]: One study in Australia found that acoustic devices had no significant effect on the behaviour of common bottlenose dolphins, harbour porpoises, Indo-Pacific humpback dolphins or dugongs.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__For shark control programs in Australia and South Africa, what is the evidence for alternative methods to nets that reduce harm to marine mammals?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Based on available evidence, several actions show effectiveness for reducing human-wildlife conflict at wild fisheries.
[Statement 2]: Use of acoustic devices on moorings was found to reduce the number of harbour seals feeding on migrating juvenile salmon in the Puntledge River.
[Statement 3]: The use of acoustic devices on fishing gear showed mixed but generally positive results for reducing human-wildlife conflict.
[Statement 4]: Acoustic devices on cod traps or fishing nets resulted in fewer collisions of humpback whales.
[Statement 5]: Acoustic devices on cod traps or fishing nets resulted in fewer entanglements of harbour porpoises, Franciscana dolphins, beaked whales and small cetaceans.
[Statement 6]: Acoustic devices reduced damage to fish catches and/or fishing nets caused by common bottlenose dolphins and seals.
[Statement 7]: The use of catch and hook protection devices on fishing gear showed variable results in reducing predation.
[Statement 8]: Net sleeves or cage and chain devices on fishing hooks reduced damage to fish catches by sperm whales, killer whales and toothed whales.
[Statement 9]: Umbrella or spider devices on fishing gear did not reduce predation in some studies.
[Statement 10]: For aquaculture systems, replacing anti-predator nets more frequently at salmon farms resulted in fewer salmon losses to harbour seal predation.
[Statement 11]: Installing cork line barriers did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery.
[Statement 12]: Switching off artificial lights on bridges did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon.
[Statement 13]: Translocating fur seals away from salmon farms resulted in more than half or nearly all of the translocated fur seals returning.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__Based on the available evidence, what are the most beneficial actions for reducing human-wildlife conflict at wild fisheries?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Based on available evidence, acoustic devices show different levels of effectiveness for reducing human-wildlife conflict at wild fisheries depending on their deployment method.
[Statement 2]: Acoustic devices on fishing gear appear to be the most effective deployment method.
[Statement 3]: Five of six controlled studies showed that acoustic devices on fishing gear reduced damage to fish catches and/or fishing nets caused by marine mammals.
[Statement 4]: Nine studies found fewer collisions or entanglements of various whale and dolphin species when acoustic devices were used on fishing nets and cod traps.
[Statement 5]: Acoustic devices on moorings showed limited evidence for reducing human-wildlife conflict.
[Statement 6]: One randomized controlled study found that deploying acoustic devices on moorings reduced harbour seals feeding on migrating juvenile salmon.
[Statement 7]: Acoustic devices based on moorings effectively modified marine mammal behavior.
[Statement 8]: Studies showed that mooring-based acoustic devices reduced the number of seals and the activity of various dolphin and porpoise species.
[Statement 9]: Acoustic devices on fishing vessels showed the least effectiveness for human-wildlife conflict reduction.
[Statement 10]: One randomized controlled study found no reduction in the predation of squid catches by dolphins when acoustic devices were used on vessels.
[Statement 11]: Acoustic devices based on vessels modified dolphin behavior, causing avoidance and reduced foraging activity.
[Statement 12]: Acoustically reflective objects attached to fishing gear showed no effectiveness.
[Statement 13]: Studies found no reduction in dolphin entanglements or whale predation when using acoustically reflective objects attached to fishing gear.
[Statement 14]: The evidence suggests that direct attachment of acoustic devices to fishing gear provides the most consistent results for reducing human-wildlife conflict compared to vessel or mooring deployment methods.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the comparative effectiveness of deploying acoustic devices on fishing gear, vessels, or moorings for reducing human-wildlife conflict at wild fisheries?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The available evidence for methods to reduce marine mammal exposure to noise from industrial activities is limited.
[Statement 2]: One study in the North Sea found that using bubble curtains or screens during pile driving resulted in harbour porpoise detections within 15 km decreasing less compared to before pile driving than at sites without bubble curtains or screens.
[Statement 3]: Four studies from the North Sea, Great Belt, and Iceland found that using acoustic devices to deter mammals from wind farm construction sites or pelagic sites reduced the activity and sightings of harbour porpoises at distances of 1-18 km from the devices.
[Statement 4]: Four studies found that using acoustic devices to deter mammals from an area caused minke whales to swim away from the devices, increase their swimming speed, and swim more directly.
[Statement 5]: Three studies from the South Atlantic, South Pacific, and UK waters found that a greater proportion of cetaceans avoided or moved away from vessels during soft start procedures with seismic airguns compared to when airguns were not firing.
[Statement 6]: The response of cetaceans to soft start procedures with seismic airguns varied by species.
[Statement 7]: Some whales remained within 900m of vessels during soft start procedures with seismic airguns.
[Statement 8]: Humpback whales responded to soft start procedures with seismic airguns by only slowing their speed without significantly altering their course.
[Statement 9]: No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of delaying or ceasing operations when mammals are detected within specified zones.
[Statement 10]: No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of reducing hammer energy during pile driving.
[Statement 11]: No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of using alternative methods instead of airguns for seismic surveys.
[Statement 12]: No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of modifying vessels to reduce noise disturbance.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the available evidence for methods aimed at reducing marine mammal exposure to noise from industrial activities like pile driving and seismic surveys?
_claude-sonnet-4__What actions are available to reduce the risk of lethal vessel collisions with large whales?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Multiple actions are available to reduce the risk of lethal vessel collisions with large whales.
[Statement 2]: Setting and enforcing vessel speed limits has demonstrated effectiveness in reducing lethal vessel collisions with large whales.
[Statement 3]: Studies show that setting vessel speed limits during specific periods in key habitats resulted in fewer North Atlantic right whale deaths caused by collisions.
[Statement 4]: Speed limit enforcement in all areas showed fewer manatee deaths compared to partial enforcement in zones only.
[Statement 5]: Diverting shipping routes to avoid whale habitats is an available action to reduce vessel collisions with large whales.
[Statement 6]: Using observers on board vessels to detect mammals can allow a vessel's course or speed to be altered to avoid collisions.
[Statement 7]: Training vessel operators on appropriate avoidance techniques can reduce collisions with large whales.
[Statement 8]: Technology-based solutions are available to reduce the risk of lethal vessel collisions with large whales.
[Statement 9]: Real-time automated tools on board vessels can be used to detect mammals and allow a vessel's course or speed to be altered.
[Statement 10]: Remote tools can be used to detect mammals in an area and allow a vessel's course or speed to be altered.
[Statement 11]: Technology and reporting systems can be used to avoid collisions between vessels and large whales.
[Statement 12]: Modifying vessels is an action that can reduce the risk of physical injury to mammals.
[Statement 13]: Reducing shipping along inland waterways is an action that can reduce the risk of vessel collisions with large whales.
[Statement 14]: With the exception of speed limits, no studies have yet been found that directly evaluated the effectiveness of most other collision-reduction actions on marine mammal populations.

[Statement 1]: The documented population-level outcomes of legally protecting marine mammals and the habitats of marine mammals show positive results across multiple species and locations.
[Statement 2]: The population of Mediterranean monk seals increased during the eight years after the islands inhabited by the seals were legally protected in the North Atlantic Ocean.
[Statement 3]: Bottlenose dolphins in the North Sea maintained similar population sizes before and after the legal protection of the dolphins' habitat.
[Statement 4]: Survival rates for Hector's dolphins in the South Pacific Ocean improved after the protection of the coastal area.
[Statement 5]: Human-caused strandings of Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphins decreased after legal protection was established in the Port River estuary.
[Statement 6]: The overall number of strandings for Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphins in the Port River estuary remained similar after legal protection was established.
[Statement 7]: Following a prohibition on hunting, populations of harbour seals and humpback whales increased over a period of 7 to 30 years in the Kattegat and Skagerrak Seas, the South Pacific Ocean, the North Atlantic Ocean, and the Southern Ocean.
[Statement 8]: One study found no significant difference in the number of mature male sperm whales 31 years after a hunting prohibition was enacted.
[Statement 9]: A review of 12 baleen whale populations showed significant increase rates for 10 of those populations during a 7 to 21-year period after the enactment of hunting prohibition legislation in the North Atlantic Ocean, the North Pacific Ocean, and the Southern Hemisphere.
[Statement 10]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of directly legally protecting marine and freshwater mammal species.
[Statement 11]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of establishing networks of legally protected areas for marine mammals.
[Statement 12]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of enforcing existing habitat protection legislation for marine mammals.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the documented population-level outcomes of legally protecting marine mammals and their habitats?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Rehabilitation programs have achieved survival rates of 10-100% for dolphins, porpoises, whales, seals, sea lions and manatees during post-release monitoring periods.
[Statement 2]: Post-release monitoring periods for rehabilitated marine mammals have ranged from three days to five years.
[Statement 3]: Approximately three-quarters of captive-reared Antillean manatees survived for at least one year after release.
[Statement 4]: Approximately two-thirds of Florida manatees survived for at least one year after release.
[Statement 5]: Some captive-reared manatees have survived for more than seven years after release.
[Statement 6]: More than a quarter of rehabilitated Hawaiian monk seals reproduced after release.
[Statement 7]: Most captive-reared Antillean manatees released into the wild reproduced.
[Statement 8]: Captive-reared and released Pacific harbour seal pups had similar survival estimates to wild pups.
[Statement 9]: Captive-reared and released Pacific harbour seal pups had similar diving behavior to wild pups.
[Statement 10]: Two of three Antillean manatees born in captivity and released into the wild survived for at least one year without further intervention.
[Statement 11]: Two of 14 Florida manatees born in captivity and released into the wild survived for at least one year without further intervention.
[Statement 12]: In captive breeding programs, 80% of common bottlenose dolphins born in captivity over two decades survived.
[Statement 13]: The survival rate of common bottlenose dolphins born in captivity increased with improved husbandry techniques.
[Statement 14]: Some rehabilitated animals died before or after release.
[Statement 15]: Some rehabilitated animals had to be returned to captivity after release.
[Statement 16]: Some rehabilitated animals, including three West Indian manatee calves, seven Hawaiian monk seal pups and one Antillean manatee calf, survived only with supplemental feeding.
[Statement 17]: At least a quarter of California sea lions treated for toxic algae poisoning and released died or had to be euthanized.
[Statement 18]: California sea lions treated for toxic algae poisoning showed altered behavior after release.
[Statement 19]: California sea lions treated for toxic algae poisoning traveled further from shore, spent less time diving or hauled out, and made shorter, shallower dives than wild sea lions.
[Statement 20]: Most captive-born Amazon river dolphins, narrow-ridged finless porpoises and Irrawaddy dolphins did not survive in captivity.
[Statement 21]: A population of Yangtze finless porpoises breeding in semi-captive conditions had low genetic diversity.
[Statement 22]: Some captive-reared animals like a grey whale calf and five pygmy and dwarf sperm whale calves either were not released or died in captivity.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the documented benefits and negative outcomes associated with captive rearing and rehabilitation of marine mammals?
